Free schedule plan Introduction In about two years, I picture myself completing my master’s program in Medical Science. My goal is to actively participate in an oncology research group, utilizing bioinformatics tools to propel advancements in the field of oncology. Currently, I am making steady progress toward this objective. Drawing on my background in Life Sciences and a growing interest in data science applied to biology, I am well-equipped to make meaningful contributions to oncology research through bioinformatics. To continue on this path, I recognize the importance of seizing educational opportunities, gaining hands-on research experience, and expanding my professional network within the relevant fields. In terms of skill development, I have chosen to explore the Bisulfite sequencing technique (BS-seq) during the “Data Science for Biology 2” course. This decision reflects the crucial role of BS-seq in epigenomics research, where it is instrumental in uncovering DNA methylation patterns and their implications for gene regulation and disease. By mastering BS-seq techniques, I aim to contribute significantly to the advancement of understanding epigenetic mechanisms and their diverse biological implications. Goals Understanding the Bisulfite conversion technique Exploring new bioinformatic packages and tools Understanding the workflow of the BS-seq Plan I’ll spend 32 hours on my free schedule to begin learning my new skill in BS-seq in across 4 days in two weeks. in the table 1 you will find my planning for the 4 days. C.elegans plate experiment Introduction Scatter plot

C.elegans plate experiment Introduction This exercise utilizes a dataset provided by J. Louter (INT/ILC) from an experiment involving adult C. elegans nematodes. The experiment aimed to investigate the effects of different compounds at varying concentrations on the reproductive output of these nematodes. Key variables in the dataset include the number of offspring (RawData), the generic name of the compound (compName), the concentration of the compound (compConcentration), and the type of experiment (expType). This dataset offers valuable insights into the dose-response relationships and the potential toxicological impacts of chemical exposure on C. elegans, serving as a model for broader biological and ecological studies. Import and inspect dataset # import C.elegans data file CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata <- read_excel( here::here( "data", "CE.LIQ.FLOW.062_Tidydata.xlsx")) # inspecting data in table format with the reactable reactable(data = CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata, defaultPageSize = 5, compact = T, highlight = T, filterable = T) # check for NA's #summary(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata) Scatter plot Pseudocode Decide which columns will be included in the scatter plot Check the units and if needed convert them to the correct units Checking and if needed change the datatypes of columns Plot the data in a scatterplot using ggplot Normalise RawData counts Set the x-axis to a log10 scale Use Jitter to avoid overlaps of points Inspection # inspect the type of data of column RawData, compName, and compConcentration CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% select( RawData, compName, compConcentration, expType) %>% map(class) ## $RawData ## [1] "numeric" ## ## $compName ## [1] "character" ## ## $compConcentration ## [1] "character" ## ## $expType ## [1] "character" After importing and inspecting the dataset, there were few things notable: The data type of “Rawdata” is currently double; it needs to be converted to integer. Additionally, it contains 5 NA values. The data type of compConcentration is currently character, which will cause an error when used on the X-axis. We need to convert it to double. The “compConcentration” values are mostly in units of nM, but for the experiments with Ethanol, the units are in percentage (pct). These values need to be converted to nM first. The compName and expType variables are currently stored as character strings. To use them effectively in our plot, we need to convert them into factors. Correction EtOH values To calculate the concentration of “Ethanol” in a solution given as a percentage and convert it to nano molar (nMol/L), follow the steps outlined below. The formula for converting the percentage of ethanol to nano molar (nMol/L) is as follows: \[ \text{nMol/L} = \left( \frac{\text{Percentage EtOH} \times \text{Density in g/L}}{\text{Molar Mass in g/mol} \times 100} \right) \times 1.000.000 \] Given resources: 0.5% EtOH 1.5% EtOH Compound knowledge: Density of EtOH: 789 g/L Molar Mass: 46,068 g/mol pseudocode Convert percentage to fraction Multiply by the density of ethanol Divide by the molar mass of ethanol Convert to nano molar perc_EtOH_to_nM <- function(percentage){ perc_EtOH <- percentage density <- 789 molar_mass <- 46.068 # Convert percentage to fraction fraction_ethanol <- perc_EtOH / 100 # Multiply by the density of ethanol concentration_g_per_L <- fraction_ethanol * density # Divide by the molar mass of ethanol concentration_mol_per_L <- concentration_g_per_L / molar_mass # Convert to nano molar concentration_nMol_per_L <- concentration_mol_per_L * 1e6 # return result return(concentration_nMol_per_L) } perc_EtOH_to_nM(.5) ## [1] 85634.28 perc_EtOH_to_nM(1.5) ## [1] 256902.8 # replace the the percentage values of EtOH with correct values in nM CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration %>% str_replace_all("^0.5$", "85634.28") CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration %>% str_replace_all("^1.5$", "256902.8") CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compUnit <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compUnit %>% str_replace_all("^pct$","nM") # check the new values new_values <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% filter(compName == "Ethanol") %>% select(compName, expType, compConcentration, compUnit) reactable(new_values, defaultPageSize = 5, compact = T, highlight = T, filterable = T) # Change "compConcentration" to double CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration <- as.double(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compConcentration) # change "compName" into a factor CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compName <- factor(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compName, levels = unique(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$compName)) # change "expType" into a factor CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$expType <- factor(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$expType, levels = unique(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata$expType)) # Checking the new datatypes and factor levels CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% select( RawData, compName, compConcentration, expType) %>% map(class) ## $RawData ## [1] "numeric" ## ## $compName ## [1] "factor" ## ## $compConcentration ## [1] "numeric" ## ## $expType ## [1] "factor" # check levels of "compName" and "expType" CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% select( compName, expType) %>% map(levels) ## $compName ## [1] "2,6-diisopropylnaphthalene" "decane" ## [3] "naphthalene" "Ethanol" ## [5] "S-medium" ## ## $expType ## [1] "experiment" "controlPositive" "controlNegative" "controlVehicleA" Scatterplot CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata # plot dataset in a scatterplot CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% ggplot(aes(x = log10(compConcentration), y = as.integer(RawData)))+ geom_point(aes(color = compName, shape = expType), size = 1.5, alpha = .8, position = position_jitter(width = 0.1), # jitter to avoid overlap na.rm = T)+ labs( title = "Scatterplot CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata", x = "log10(compound conc.) in nM)", y = "Number of offspring counted", color = "Compound name", shape = "Experiment condition")+ theme_bw(base_size = 12)+ scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") # colour-blind friendly colours Figure 0.2: Number of C. elegans offspring after various exposures. The number of offspring was counted after incubating nematodes in S-medium for an unspecified period, exposed to different concentrations of naphthalene, 2,6-di-isopropylnaphthalene, decane, and ethanol. The negative control, S-medium, is represented as having a ‘compConcentration’ of 0%, which is barely shown in the graph because the log10 of 0 is undefined. Analysis plan Pseudocode Analysing Compound Concentrations: Load the data (import dataset). Filter the data to separate concentrations by compound (filter concentrations). Create a bar graph representing the concentrations for each compound, with standard deviation bars as error bars (plotting). Conduct a Shapiro-Wilk test separately for each group to assess normality (normality check). Perform an analysis of variance (ANOVA) test to determine if there are significant differences between the compound groups (ANOVA test). If the ANOVA test yields significance, proceed with post hoc tests to compare specific groups (post hoc test). Draw conclusions based on the results obtained (conclusion). Comparing LC50 Curves: Load the LC50 data (import dataset). Filter the data to obtain LC50 concentrations for each compound (filter concentration). Plot the LC50 curves for each compound (plotting). Calculate the 95% confidence intervals for each LC50 curve (95% confidence interval). Assess the overlap between the 95% confidence intervals of different compounds (check overlap). Draw conclusions based on the comparison of LC50 curves and the overlap of confidence intervals (conclusion). Normalising CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata We are interested in how the number of nematode offspring changes after incubation with a substance compared to the normal situation. This information cannot be discerned from the above graph because the number of offspring in the negative control is not shown. To address this, I normalize the data by expressing the number of offspring in each measurement as a fraction of the average number of offspring after incubation in S-medium. # filter on "controlNegative" data CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% filter(expType == "controlNegative") # calculate mean of "RawData" of the filtered dataset contNeg_mean <- mean(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg$RawData) contNeg_mean # check contNeg_mean ## [1] 85.9 # create a normalised column with the normalised values. CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata %>% mutate(Normalised = RawData/mean(contNeg_mean)) # check what mean RawData is mean(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm$RawData, na.rm=T) ## [1] 68.10423 # check the normalisation values are a fraction of 1 CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg_norm <- CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm %>% filter(expType == "controlNegative") # check if mean value of controlNegative is equal to "1" contNegNorm_mean <- mean(CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_contNeg_norm$Normalised) contNegNorm_mean ## [1] 1 # check if the normalised values are a fraction of "1". CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm %>% select(compName, expType, compConcentration, RawData, Normalised) %>% reactable( defaultPageSize = 5, compact = T, highlight = T, filterable = T, columns = list( Normalised = colDef(minWidth = 200) )) Scatterplot normalised CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata_norm %>% ggplot(aes(x = log10(compConcentration), y = as.integer(Normalised)))+ geom_point(aes(color = compName, shape = expType), size = 1.5, alpha = 0.8, position = position_jitter(width = .1), # jitter to avoid overlap na.rm = T)+ geom_vline(xintercept = -1.25, linetype = "dashed", color = "red", size = .5)+ labs( title = "Scatterplot normalised CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata", y = "Normalised counted number of offspring", x = "log10(compound conc.) in nM", color = "Compound name", shape = "Experiment condition")+ theme_bw(base_size = 12)+ scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") # colour-blind friendly colours Figure 0.3: Number of C. elegans offspring after normalising CE_LIQ_FLOW_062_Tidydata dataset. For each exposure to one of the substances at a specific concentration, the fraction of offspring was calculated relative to the number of offspring in the negative control. Conclusion In the positive control group, significantly fewer nematodes were born after incubation in 1.5% ethanol compared to S-medium, as indicated by a fraction much smaller than 1. At substance concentrations below approximately 0.06 nM (see red dashed line or log10 values below -1.25), the number of nematodes born was either similar to, less than, or greater than the number born in the negative control group. Therefore, at these lower concentrations, there appears to be no noticeable effect on the number of offspring. However, at higher concentrations of the three tested substances, fewer nematodes were born compared to the negative control, indicating a significant impact on offspring production.

Reproducible Research Open peer review Introduction The COVID-19 pandemic has underscored the critical role of open science and reproducible research. Open science facilitates the free exchange of findings, while reproducible research ensures that publications are both accessible and verifiable, thereby enhancing transparency and trust in scientific conclusions. Together, these practices drive scientific progress forward [1]. The transparency criteria of Reproducibility and reporting practices in COVID-19 preprint manuscripts was used to examine the reproducibility of an published article. I’ll peer review Applying Cell Painting in Non-Tumorigenic Breast Cells to Understand Impacts of Common Chemical Exposures from bioRxiv using the transparency criteria shown in table 2. Article overview Researchers used Cell Painting to study the effects of various chemicals on mammary cells to understand their potential links to breast cancer. They examined 16 chemicals and 21 small molecules, analysing over 3000 cellular features. By comparing their findings with human exposure data, they identified similarities between certain chemicals and known pathways. Notably, a pesticide metabolite showed similarities to a Wnt pathway activator, suggesting a potential mechanism for breast cancer risk. This study highlights Cell Painting’s utility in understanding the effects of common environmental toxins on breast cancer[2]. Peer review Table 2. The Ripeta team analyzed eight reproducibility criteria [1]. Transparency Criteria Definition REsponse Type Score Study Purpose A concise statement in the introduction of the article, often in the last paragraph, that establishes the reason the research was conducted. Also called the study objective. Binary yes Data Availability Statement A statement, in an individual section offset from the main body of text, that explains how or if one can access a study’s data. The title of the section may vary, but it must explicitly mention data; it is therefore distinct from a supplementary materials section. Binary yes Data Location Where the article’s data can be accessed, either raw or processed. Found Value yes; all in paper or supplementary fils Study Location Author has stated in the methods section where the study took place or the data’s country/region of origin. Binary; Found Value no Author Review The professionalism of the contact information that the author has provided in the manuscript. Tier 3 Ethics Statement A statement within the manuscript indicating any ethical concerns, including the presence of sensitive data. Binary no Funding Statement A statement within the manuscript indicating whether or not the authors received funding for their research. Binary yes Code Availability Authors have shared access to the most updated code that they used in their study, including code used for analysis. Binary no Conclusion This article meets most criteria at a sufficient level. However, it falls short in a couple of key areas. Firstly, it does not specify the study locations in the methods section. Secondly, there is no code available for the analysis, hindering the replicability of the results. These shortcomings could impact the article’s reception in open peer review processes, highlighting areas for improvement in transparency and reproducibility. Furthermore, there was no ethics statement mentioned. This may not be relevant in this study, but it should be included in the ethical statement section. With these shortcomes, the article does not pass the open peer review. Reproducible analysis From this blog, I chose a open source paper using the OSF website to reproduce a peace of code that is used in the study. From this paper, I have reproduced a piece of code. The associated code and datasets can be found here. The codes in this RMarkdown were used to create the figures presented in this paper. On a scale from 1 (very poor) to 5 (very good), I rate the readability of the codes in this file a 4. Below, I reproduce a portion of the data to recreate figure 1 from the paper. It was easily to reproduce this figure, with a difficulty rating of 5 on a scale from 1 (very difficult) to 5 (very easy). R package I build an R package named {SynopsisPackage}. This package identify the data format and import the dataset if the correct data format is provided. After successfully importing the dataset, the package will provide a comprehensive summary that includes the following metadata: Class: The datasets’ classification. Data Type: The data type. Dimensions: The datasets’ dimensions. Structure: The datasets’ structure. Column Names: The column names within the dataset. Missing Values: Detailed information about missing values within the dataset. Imported Dataset: The dataset itself, loaded into your environment. By using this package, users can easily identify, read, and understand the basic structure and characteristics of their data. The package can be found in my github and can be installed and used with synopsis(). Projecticum: Pediatric Cancer Introduction the past decade, we have witnessed a change from traditional invasive techniques for diagnosing and monitoring cancer to more innovative and non-invasive methods, such as liquid biopsies. This new approach has revolutionized the field of clinical oncology, offering significant benefits such as simplified tumour sampling and personalized therapeutic strategies [3]. Liquid biopsies involve the isolation and analysis of tumour-derived samples, such as circulating tumour cells (CTC) and circulating tumour DNA (ctDNA), from the bodily fluids of cancer patients. Once these biomarkers are extracted, they provide invaluable information about tumour characteristics such as progression, staging, heterogeneity, gene mutations, and clonal evolution. Thus, liquid biopsies have improved our understanding of tumours, leading to better detection, ongoing monitoring, and personalized treatment [3]. cfDNA Cell-free DNA (cfDNA) is a term used to describe small fragments of DNA that circulate freely in bodily fluids such as blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid. Unlike DNA contained within intact cells, cfDNA is released into the bloodstream through various physiological processes, including apoptosis, necrosis, and active secretion [4]. The origins of cfDNA are diverse and can include contributions from normal cells, as well as cells undergoing pathological processes such as cancer. In the context of liquid biopsy, which involves the analysis of biomarkers in bodily fluids for diagnostic or monitoring purposes, cfDNA holds particular significance [3, 5]. In cancer patients, cfDNA can contain genetic mutations or other alterations that are characteristic of the tumour. These small fragments of DNA are called ctDNA. By isolating and analysing cfDNA from a blood sample, clinicians can gain valuable insights into the genetic profile of a patient’s tumour, potentially facilitating early detection, monitoring of disease progression, assessment of treatment response, and detection of resistance mutations [5]. R shiny app The R shiny app: A place where you can “make an interactive web application that executes R code on the backend”. The functionality and user friendly interactivity of the R shiny is needed for our project for 2 main reasons. When looking at data, you need to be able to visualize it. Then when this data is visualized, you are still able to give user inputs that can adjust and modify the visualization and results that you are looking for [6]. When working with the ct- and cf-DNA, we want to be able to really visualize and capture what this data means for us. But in the mean time we also would like to give inputs for our charts and graphs, that makes it so that we can really pinpoint on the things we are sought after. By having a web application that can run R calculations on the background, we can create an user friendly environment, that can be used by more than just data scientist. References

Parameterisation of COVID-19 Datasets Introduction Frequently, it is desirable to adjust the parameters within a single analysis, such as changing the dataset used for the analysis. Below, I will illustrate an example of how RMarkdown parametrisation allows for easy switching between different parameters. The used dataset is form European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and can be found here. The dataset contains the reports of Covid-19 cases and deaths Parameters Parameter for country Parameter for year Parameter for month Pseudocode Load the dataset in Select data for the parameters create automatic naming output plot the graphs #read the Dataset sheet from ECDC data <- read.csv("https://opendata.ecdc.europa.eu/covid19/nationalcasedeath_eueea_daily_ei/csv", na.strings = "", fileEncoding = "UTF-8-BOM") Visualisation Covid-19 cases data_plot %>% filter(month == params$month) %>% ggplot(aes(x = day, y = cases)) + geom_line(size = .8, color = "orange") + labs(title = paste("COVID-19 cases in",country, month, year), x = "Day", y = "New cases")+ scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, max(data_plot$cases))) + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1, 31)) + theme_bw() Figure 0.4: Covid-19 cases in Netherlands March 2020 Covid-19 deaths data_plot %>% filter(month == params$month) %>% ggplot(aes(x = day, y = deaths)) + geom_line(size = .8, color = "red") + labs(title = paste("Covid-19 deaths in",country, month, year), x = "Day", y = "New deaths") + scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, max(data_plot$deaths))) + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1, 31)) + theme_bw() Figure 0.5: Covid-19 deaths in Netherlands March 2020

BS-Seq Introduction DNA methylation plays a crucial role in many biological processes, such as gene expression, embryonic development, cellular proliferation, differentiation, and chromosome stability[7]. Abnormal patterns of DNA methylation are correlated with the loss of DNA homoeostasis and DNA instability, which can lead to inherited or acquired diseases like cancer.[7, 8]. In mammals, the most commonly methylation is at the carbon-5 atom in the cytosine ring within cytosine-guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. This occurs by a enzymatic reaction that is catalysed by three DNA methyltransferases (DNMTs)[7, 8]. After DNA replication, the newly synthesized DNA strand undergoes methylation modification. DNMT1 catalyzes the covalent addition of a methyl group to the unmethylated strand. While DNMT1 performs the majority of DNA methylation, DNMT3a and DNMT3b provide support when DNMT1 misses a site[8]. Bisulfite conversion Bisulfite conversion is considered the gold standard for determining DNA methylation status. During this process, treatment of DNA with sodium bisulfite converts unmethylated cytosines to uracil. These uracils are then converted to thymines during PCR amplification, while methylated cytosines remain unchanged (Figure 6)[7, 9]. Figure 0.6: After bisulfite treatment, all unmethylated cytosines (C) are converted to thymines (T). A C-peak indicates the presence of 5-methylcytosine (5mC) in the genome. Complete methylation or full conversion of a single residue is represented by a single peak. The presence of both C- and T-peaks suggests partial methylation or possibly incomplete bisulfite conversion[7]. Bismark Bismark is a software tool used in the field of bioinformatics for the analysis of bisulfite sequencing data, which is a technique used to study DNA methylation[10]. It aligns bisulfite treated reads to a reference genome, identifies methylated cytosines, and generates methylation calls at single-base resolution[10, 11]. Bismark works with a aligner and a reference genome. I chose for the Bowtie2 aligner and the Homo sapiens genome as reference genome. Data Bismark includes a test BS-seq dataset containing 10,000 single-end shotgun BS reads from human embryonic stem (ES) cells. The reads are trimmed to 50 bp, and the base call qualities are Sanger encoded with Phred scores of 33. Additionally, I found two BS-seq fastq files at the NCBI. The identifiers of the fastq files are SRR9834204 and SRR29020037. SRR9834204: This identifier has a Phred score of 37, and is from the paper Whole Blood Targeted Bisulfite Sequencing Validates Differential Methylation in C6orf10 gene of Patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis and can be accessed here. SRR29020037: this identifier has a Phred score of 37, and is from the paper MSA: scalable DNA methylation screening BeadChip for high-throughput trait association studies and its identifier can be found here Genome preparation The first step is to set the reference genome with the bismark_genome_preparation code. Therefore, I downloaded the Homo sapiens genome from the Ensembl website and placed it in the genome folder. Bismark will create two individual folders within the specified directory, one for the C->T converted genome and another for the G->A converted genome. After generating these converted versions of the genome, Bismark will index them in parallel using the bowtie2-build indexer. Running bismark_genome_preparation # Use datasets to download biological sequence data across all domains of life from NCBI. curl -o datasets 'https://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pub/datasets/command-line/v2/mac/datasets' # (downlaod dataformat to convert metadata from JSON Lines format to other formats) # curl -o dataformat 'https://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pub/datasets/command-line/v2/mac/dataformat' # make them executeble chmod +x datasets #dataformat # download the homo sapiens genome with the ncbi tool "datasets" ./data/tools/datasets download genome accession GCF_000001405.40 --dehydrated --filename human_GRCh38_dataset.zip # unzip the dataset unzip human_GRCh38_dataset.zip -d human_GRCh38_dataset # rehydrate to excess the data ./data/tools/datasets rehydrate --directory human_GRCh38_dataset/ USAGE: bismark_genome_preparation [options] <path_to_genome_folder> ./Bismark/bismark_genome_preparation --path_to_aligner "./data/tools/bowtie2" --verbose "./data/genomes/human_GRCh28_datset/ncbi_dataset/data/GCF_000001405.40/GRCh38.p14.fna" Alignment This step involves bisulfite alignment and methylation calling. Bismark requires two main inputs: The directory containing the genome of interest, including the unmodified genome (.fa or .fasta files) and the two bisulfite genome subdirectories generated during the Bismark Genome Preparation step. The sequence file(s) to be analyzed (in FastQ or FastA format). All other parameters are optional. Running bismark USAGE: bismark [options] <genome_folder> {-1 <mates1> -2 <mates2> | <singles>} # Typical alignment example (tolerating one non-bisulfite mismatch per read): #bismark --bowtie1 -n 1 -l 50 /data/genomes/homo_sapiens/GRCh37/ test_dataset.fastq This will produce two output files: test_dataset.fastq_bismark.bam (contains all alignments plus methylation call strings) test_dataset.fastq_bismark_SE_report.txt (contains alignment and methylation summary) Deduplication This command will deduplicate the Bismark alignment BAM file, retaining only one read per unique position and orientation. This step is recommended for whole-genome bisulfite samples but should not be used for reduced representation libraries, such as RRBS, amplicon, or target enrichment libraries. deduplicate_bismark --bam [options] <filenames> Methylation extraction Running bismark_methylation_extractor USAGE: bismark_methylation_extractor [options] <filenames> # A typical command to extract context-dependent (CpG/CHG/CHH) methylation could look like this: #bismark_methylation_extractor -s --comprehensive test_dataset.fastq_bismark.sam This will produce three output files: CpG_context_test_dataset.fastq_bismark.txt CHG_context_test_dataset.fastq_bismark.txt CHH_context_test_dataset.fastq_bismark.txt References

1 DSFB2_portfolio Welcome! My name is Naresh de Bruijn, and I am pleased to introduce you to this Gitbook. This project was built using the CRAN R package {bookdown}, inspired by Yihui Xie. Within this Gitbook, you will find a collection of RMarkdown files containing my portfolio assignments. These assignments demonstrate the skills I acquired during the Data Sciences for Biology minor at University of Applied Sciences Utrecht. This Gitbook is linked to a GitHub Pages website, which serves as my final product for the DSFB2 Workflows course.
